text: All right.
So let's get started.

Thanks for the
kind introduction.
Hi, everyone.
I'm Albert.

I'm a fifth year PhD student
with Professor Karen Liu.

And today, I'll talk about
learning physics-based models--

to learn generalizable
robotic manipulation.

And so I'll try to answer
three questions today.
All right.
Yeah.
Yeah.

So first, what is missing
in robotic manipulation?
And what causes this deficiency?

And lastly, how can
physics based models
help us in this regard?

And so I'll start with
answering what is missing
in robotic manipulation today.
Sorry.

I think my computer
just hanged--
a second.
All right.
Yeah, sorry about the hiccup.
And so just quickly reiterate.

I'll try to answer
these three questions

today regarding
robotic manipulation.

And so I'll start
with the first one.

What is missing in robotic
manipulation today?

And in the past few
years we've seen

a lot of very impressive
robotic manipulation

demos, many of which originate
from the robot learning
community.

And robots are able to achieve
very crazy demos and tasks

that one can only dream
about 10 years ago.

And so this begs the question
has robotic manipulation been

solved, and do we
need to do anything

besides just getting more
data and scaling our models?
And my answer is no.

And despite the
community's strong push

on getting more data to train
on bigger and bigger models,

we're still far from solving
robotic manipulation today.

The policies that we get
from learning methods

are not generalizable
nor robust.

And the state of
the art algorithms,

such as diffusion policy
and reinforcement learning,

are not able to tackle
these challenges.

And so diffusion policy-- as
an example, the first video

I showed, it's relatively
stable to train,

and it can learn very
multimodal actions.

But they have-- as
we all know, it's

limited in
generalizability, and it's

sensitive to the
demonstration data set size.
And so in the video I showed--

probably one will
have to retrain

the policy for
each of the shapes
you're trying to manipulate.
And then the other big--

the other big algorithm
reinforcement learning

is it can learn very
sophisticated emergent behaviors

and has more robustness
in execution.

But to train a
policy, it tends to be

a very expensive and
tedious tuning process.

And the learn policy
is task specific.

And so in the
second video I show,

they actually are only able to
do the task on one object on one
environment.

And so we should then
ponder the question,
what causes this deficiency?
Why is manipulation difficult?

And the key lies in the
rich physical constraints

that govern manipulation,
which arguably

exceeds the complexity of any
other robotic applications.

And some of the notable
ones that I'll cover today

include collision and robot
reachability constraints,

contact modes, forced
closure, and friction cone.

And then the existence
of these constraints

make learning manipulation
exceedingly difficult

as the motion must adhere
to these constraints.

And breaking these constraints
will lead to failed execution,
and the task will not work.

And so diving into the three
constraints that we have--

the first one, collision
and robot reachability.

So this falls in the
category of kinematics,

and these are mostly
geometric constraints.

So they depend on the
shape of the object

we're trying to manipulate
and the scene that we're
manipulating.

And these are highly
non-convex constraints,

as we know from
kinematic solves.

It is possible to get
a local solution when

we try to enforce these,
but it is very difficult
to get a global solution.

So the second category of
constraint I'll talk about
is contact mode.

And this describes the contact
configuration between the robot,
the object and the scene.

So contact mode directly
impacts the system's dynamics

due to what's called hybrid
dynamics in the literature.

So if you imagine the example
on the upper right corner,

if there is no
environmental contact,

we can never get the
contact force with, say,
this wall in the environment.

Whereas if there
is contact, which

is a different
dynamic mode, then we

are able to get
the contact force.

And this is also
largely geometric.

Again, it very much depends
on the shape of the object

and the shape of
the environment.

And it is possible to detect
and enforce these constraints,

whether with tactile
force sensing.

And there are classical
control tools,

such as compliant or
force control, that
will allow us to use these.

But they're generally rather
difficult to work with.

And then the last
type of constraint

I'd like to talk about is full
disclosure and friction cone.

These mostly concern
robotic grasping.

And forced closure
describes, in a nutshell,

the sum of external forces
and torques equal to zero.

So that's required when
we want to hold an object.

And then there's also a slightly
more advanced ingredient,

where we try to reject
any possible disturbances
on the object.

And then for friction
cone, typically, we

use Coulomb friction
model in literature.

And both of these
are conditioned
on the contact point.

So the forced closure of
friction cone condition

depends on how we decide to
make contact with the object.

And there are rich
computational tools,

such as formulating things
as a quadratic optimization

and whatnot that allows us to
leverage these constraints.

And so what are some
common attributes of these?

So all these three
types of constraints

are non-convex but
mostly differentiable.

We can either they're directly
differentiable, or they can be--

the subgradient can be
obtained through smoothing.

And because of
the non-convexity,

they are pretty computationally
expensive to work with.

Again, we won't be able to
get a global solution if we

want to just simply
solve an optimization
with these constraints.

And they are extensively
covered by past literature--

the literature that
predates robot learning.

There is a lot of work
on kinematics dynamics,

and there are also
classical control theory

tools that allow us to use
this physical constraints.

And then lastly and
most importantly,
they all stem from physics.

And in particular, mostly
from classical mechanics
and kinematics and dynamics.

So we can model these
constraints reasonably well.

And so that brings us
to the third question.

How can we leverage
physics-based model

to overcome the challenges
in robotic manipulation?

So at a high level, I
will present a few ways
to combine these physics--

to bake physics-based
models into robot learning.

And the first one is to
move expensive analytical
computations offline.

And again, recall that a
lot of these constraints

are non-convex, so we can try to
move that computation before we

execute the task by,
say, generating data sets

or creating heuristics
or trying to learn

a heuristic from the
offline generated data.

And then the second one, again,
tying to the non-convexity,

is that we can try to solve
these problems with learning.
So that can come in two ways.

First, we try to learn
an initial guess,

so that we see the
non-convex solve better.

Or we can use it
a different way,

where we try to refine a network
output with these constraints

and essentially solve
a local problem.

And so in this talk,
I'll present three

challenging manipulation
tasks and hovering

dexterous grasping,
dexterous pregrasping,
and extrinsic manipulation.

And I will show how using
these physical constraints

can help us achieve these
manipulation objectives more
efficiently.

And so we'll start off
with dextrous grasping.
So what is dexterous grasping?

This refers to grasping
an object using
a multi-fingered hand.
And why is it difficult?

A dexterous multi-fingered
hand has way

higher degrees of freedom
compared to a parallel gripper.

So we're looking at over
20 degrees of freedom

for fully actuated
four-finger hand

versus approximately
7 degrees of freedom
for a parallel gripper.

And there are a lot
more constraints

that occur in
dexterous grasping--

collision reachability,
force closure, friction cone.
They all show up.

And in particular, force
closure and friction cone

do not come for free
in dexterous hands,

whereas they're pretty
trivial in parallel gripper

because if you have two grippers
just closing in on each other,

then you get forced closure
and friction cone for free.

And dexterous grasping
is a very powerful tool

for grasping objects
because if we do it right,

we can grab a wide range
of different objects.

So imagine how a human would
use the five fingers to pick up
things in the real world.

And we can also
provide very diverse

grasping strategies--
like, say, one

can grasp an object
from the side

and from many other
different configurations.

And so in this work,
we propose a pipeline

to generate dexterous
grasping by combining
learning and optimization.

So in particular, we started
off with building a grasp
data set with analytical model.

Again, this is an expensive
process, but it is done offline.

And then we can train a
generative grasp point
predictor.

So in particular, a conditional
variational autoencoder

using this data
set that we built.

So if we look at
the figure up here--
yeah.

So let's say we're
given an object.

We can train this
model to predict where
we should place the fingers.

For example, the red,
green, and blue points here.

And then what happens if the
prediction does not actually

satisfy the physical
constraints?

So now, we can actually solve
a local optimization problem,

assuming that the network gives
us a reasonable initial guess.

So we can massage the
location of the grasp point

if we compare the left
side and right side,

so that it satisfies the
collision rule by reachability

and force closure and
friction cone constraints.

So on the left side, we can
see that the best contact

force we can achieve is
the three forces here,

which clearly do not
sum to zero because I

think it ends up with a
net force this direction.

Whereas once we solve
this local optimization,

we can apply contact forces
that will result in a zero
external wrench on the object.

And thereby, we can
successfully grasp the object.

And how well does
this work in practice?

So we put this on the robot,
and we achieve nearly 90%

success rate over 20
objects and 120 trials.

And these objects
range from objects

that we gave during
training, and things

that have never been seen before
or similar shape-- everything
in between.

And in particular,
I would like to note

that in our pipeline, because
we have a generative model,

we're able to grasp a lot
of different configurations
even for the same objects.

And the robot can use
multi-modal strategies

to ultimately pick
up the object.

And there's also certain objects
that we try that clearly cannot

be picked up with
a parallel gripper,

but with a dexterous hand
and with a good enough grasp

generation pipeline, we're able
to pick them up-- no problem.
OK.

So the takeaway of this
dexterous grasping task

is that at a high level, we
can generate a grasp data set

with physics, learn
a grasp predictor,

and then refine the prediction
with this optimization
that we formulate.

And in particular, that
considers the friction cone
and force closure.

And then finally,
we can also use

kinematics to solve for the
hand collision for this.

I believe it's 22 degrees
of freedom problem.

And so moving on to
the second task--
dexterous pregrasping.

So what is pregrasping,
and why does it
matter So in the real world--

so previously in
the grasping case,

we assumed that the object
is sitting out in the open.

But this is often not the
case in the real world.

The object that
we want to pick up

might be occluded and
thereby ungraspable.

And we need to move the
target object in certain ways

before we are able to reach
a graspable pose and then

establish a grasp or rigid
linkage to the object
with the robot.

And note that this
is made possible

by the use of a dexterous
hand because there's

a lot more freedom in how we
can interact with the object.
And so why is this difficult?

First of all, identifying
a good pregrasp

is very challenging because
a good pregrasp is only

defined by how good the
grasp it can lead to.

And this is a very
computationally expensive query.

And the computing pregrasp
itself is also very expensive

because how should we
move the fingers around?

How should we
contact the objects
to achieve this pre grasp?

And of course, there's a lot
of possible collisions, given

that the object is in a lot of
clutter and so on and so forth.

And so our insight
is that we need

only at least one environment
contact during a pregrasp,

and we only need two fingers
to establish this graph.

So these observations allow
us to reduce the search space
and use model-based method.

So we propose this pipeline,
where we do an offline training

to construct a
contact state graph,

do a trajectory optimization,
and synthesize hand motion.
And I'll cover this in detail.

And so first the
offline training.

So again, defining a
good grasp is difficult,

but defining a good
grasp is relatively easy,
as we did in the first task.

So we can learn a
grasp generator,

and we condition
this, again, based

on the observation
that in a pregrasp
we need at most two fingers.
So we learn a grasp generator.

So we complete the
rest of the finger,
given two of the contacts.

And then we can also
learn a score function--

like a heuristic--
to decide, hey,
is this pregrasp good or not.

So this offloads the expensive
computation to offline.

And then now, we can
plan a contact transition
with contact state graph.

So what this means is
that we build this graph

based on where the fingers are
placed on the object surface.
So these forms the nodes.

And then based on how we can
transition between them, we
create the edges and then--

and we can also train
the scoring function.

I think was shown
earlier here-- that

will tell us whether this
contact is a good configuration
or not.
And so now, we have this graph.

We can perform essentially
a trajectory optimization

problem conditioned on selecting
one of the paths on the graph.

And so intuitively
what this means

is that we select where the
fingers should largely contact,

and we massage it
around, decide what
is the best trajectory to take.

And then that gives us a physics
realistic trajectory, where

as shown here, we can see
that we place two fingers,

pivot the plate, and then
put the rest of the fingers
onto the plate.

And so lastly, we can just--
now that we have the fingertip

contact locations, we can just
synthesize the full hand motion

with kinematics, and
that looks like this.

And so we try this on a
lot of environments, where

we can't directly
establish a grasp,

and our pipeline is able to
achieve efficient pregrasp
planning.

And so you can see that
these are physics realistic,
and they satisfy physics.

And so the takeaway
of this project--

again, we first we
train a scoring function
to rank the contact states.

And then we train
our grasp predictor

to complete a grasp, given
the thumb and the index finger
contacts.

And then we use the
contact mode to guide

how to navigate this
pregrasp planning process.

And then we finally
synthesize hand motion

with collision and reachability,
basically solving kinematics.

And then so the third
task I will talk about
is extrinsic manipulation.
What is extrinsic manipulation?

It's manipulating an object
using environment contexts.

This is a very versatile
mode of interaction.

And recall in the
previous case, we actually

do sometimes do this
with the dexterous hand.

And it's very challenging
because again, this also

has a lot of very many different
contact configurations,

difficult to plan, and there's
a lot of sim-to-real challenge

because we don't know their,
say, friction coefficient
and whatnot.

And so our insight here
is we can take a divide
and conquer approach.

In particular, we claim
that extrinsic manipulation

can be broken down into
primitives based on the contact
configuration.

So here, we show two
primitives, where

the robot contacts the
object and pushes it

and then pivoting
it as a second one.

And then within the same
contact configuration,

we can reasonably train
a policy that is robust.

So with reinforcement
learning standard tools.

But the problem
is, how do we-- now

that we have, say, a primitive
policy for each of the contact

configuration, how do
we stitch them together?

Because there are different
contact requirements
for doing different things.

We can pivot an
object if it's not
in contact with anything else.

And so this project builds a
framework using physical models
to enforce these constraints.

And so as an overview, we built
a primitive library, defined

contact requirements, like
a robot object and robot

environment, and object
environment contact.
We take a demonstration.

And then we can remap this
task to different scenes

and different objects by
retargeting the contact
configuration.

And so we define these four
primitives-- pushing, pulling,

pivoting and grasping with a
mixture of classical control
tools and learning based tools.

Each of them stay within the
same contact configuration.

And then we come up with a
way to describe contacts.

In particular, the environment
object contacts and the robot
object context.

And then robot is assumed
to be able to move freely
between contact transitions.

And then we take
one demonstration

from the human to fix the
sequence of primitives
we try to use.

So this is very efficient--
just one demonstration,

and it doesn't even
have to be on the robot.

We label the primitives that are
used during the demo collection.

So in this case, we push it,
and then we pivot the object.

And then we run the contact
retargeting framework

that we built based on kinematic
and contact mode constraints.

So we map over the object state,
solve an inverse kinematics

to make sure the state
satisfy the contact

requirements for that specific
object shape and scene shape.
And then we fit--

now that we fixed the
object, we move the robot

to establish the desired
robot object contact.

And then we are able
to execute this task
on a variety of scenes.

So here, we show that the one
demonstration being transferred

to various different objects of
very different shapes and sizes
and a different environment.

And so we can achieve long
horizon tasks, I say--

including up to four different
contact configurations
with the same primitives that--

we prepare one set of primitive,
but then by mapping the contact
configuration we are able to--
All right.
Yeah.

So by mapping the
contact configuration,

we're able to achieve the
same task on a variety
of different objects.
Yeah.

So in the interest
of time, I think
I'll fast forward this part.

And so the takeaway for this
project is we Can build a divide

and conquer framework based
on contact constraints using
physical models.

And then we can learn
goal conditions--

we can train goal
conditioned motion primitives
with standard learning tools.

And then we stitch
these together

with our physics-based
constraints

and achieve long horizon tasks
that are otherwise impossible.

And so in this talk, I've
covered three tasks--

dexterous grasping, dexterous
pregrasping, and extrinsic
manipulation.

And so all of them use
the analytical methods

to make the computation
more efficient,

moving expensive
computation offline,

and then ensuring that the
learning methods satisfy

physical constraints
at all time.

And so with that, I
would like to go back

to the three questions I asked
at the start of the talk.

What is missing in
robotic manipulation?
Generalizability and robustness.

The policies we have
nowadays are mostly fragile.

And what causes
this deficiency is

that there are a lot of
complicated physical constraints
and manipulation.

And how can we use physical
models to solve this?

And we can do it by synthetic
data set generation,

robust constraint
satisfaction, composability,

and multitask
generalization, as shown
in the three examples I gave.

And so I would like to thank
my wonderful collaborators

for making these
projects possible.

And that's the
conclusion of my talk,
and I'm happy to take questions.
[APPLAUSE]

In dextrous grasping, why does
one finger often stick out,
while the others are grabbing?
I'll just repeat the question.

The question was why
does one finger stick out

in the dextrous
grasping project?

The reason for that
particular one,

we only consider
using the contact,
which is the minimum needed.

So the fourth finger is
just kind of sitting there.

But essentially, the same math
works for more fingers as well.
I have a related question.

So the pregrasp, you said
you require two fingers,

but it seemed like
what you're doing

is reaching them with one
finger to pull out the book.
Why two fingers?

So the question is, in
the pregrasp project,
it seems like--
why two fingers?

[INAUDIBLE] in the bookcase,
we only had one finger.

And the answer is that we
need [? apples, ?] too.

Basically, the
thought process is

that we would take two
fingers plus the environment.

So that's three
points of contact,
which forms a rigid caging.

But then, of course, if
it was a patch contact

on the environment,
like the book, then
we really only need one finger.
Any other questions?

So about your
first project, when

you do the [INAUDIBLE]
generation,

looks like your [INAUDIBLE]
started with an offline learning
grasp generator.

Then, you have a model-based
optimization procedure to refine
the grasp [INAUDIBLE].

So for any given
new grasp, you do

need to have a shape or some
kind of model of the object
to run your optimization.

If that is the case, can
you run the whole process
without the learned part?
Can you run a--

and also do a model-based
grasp in point generation?

And how does your method
compare with that?

I'm not sure if I
got the last part.

So I'm basically saying
that the information

available to your method also
supports a purely learning
free approach.

Since you have the model
for every single grasp,

technically you can run a
more traditional grasp point
generator [INAUDIBLE].

Have you ever compared your
method with [INAUDIBLE]?
So to repeat the question is--

the question is, we basically
have full information.

And so why don't we just
run a learning free method
to directly generate the grasp?

And that goes back
to the question
of the global optimization.

Because it's very
hard to come up

with this full 22 degree
of freedom solution
if we start off from scratch.

And so what the learning give
us is essentially a good local--
good initial guess.
And then if we--

so learning also can
see the initial guess

differently so that we get
diverse grasp configuration even
for the same observation.

So you're basically saying that
randomly sampled good grasp
or [INAUDIBLE] were very hard?
Yeah.
That makes sense.
Thanks.
[INAUDIBLE] problem, it was--
I don't know.

I was thinking about
this and thinking,

the hard part is not so much
to choose the initial contact

state, but rather the
motion planning that

is required to get the
object into a state such

that you can then
grasp, is that correct?

So that's as much
accessibility problem
as it is a contact problem.

The question is, the motion
planning part should be--

what is the motion planning part
is [INAUDIBLE] not the hard part

as opposed to the initial
contact stage selection?

So I think the
short answer is yes.

And that's why it is a very
computationally expensive thing
to evaluate.
Because we select the pre-grasp.

We have to go through the
whole motion planning process

to decide, hey,
it's good or not.

But then that's why we
learn a score function.

Because now, we see
the pre-grasp data,

and we can have a
guess of how good this

will be without having to
solve the full motion planning
problem.

And we solve the motion
planning problem all fine.
I have one more.

So it's actually
really cool to see

it doing the planning and
work, and picking things up.

And then you get to a good
result that's 87% successful.

And then I think if
you actually want

to use this in the real
world, 87% successful
isn't nearly enough.

So can you give us some
insights into what's--

where it's failing and what's
going to be the next step
to make it even better?

So the question is
the 87% success rate

we see is not enough
for deployment.
And what can we do about it?
And so I think this--

a lot of this goes down
to engineering challenges.

Like, say, the hand overheat
and the break, or we

didn't bother coding up
collision constraints
with the table.

So the hand might jam its pinkie
into the table and whatnot.
And so I think--

I believe people call this
the last mile problem.

Because going from 0% to
90% is just about as hard
as going from 90 to 95.
And so there's--

I think in general, there's just
a lot more engineering work.
[INAUDIBLE]
[INAUDIBLE]

So there are ways to I think
it's less principled in a sense.
